content: This renames a few lemmas on Real.exp that are not in the Real namespace to use "rexp" instead of "exp" in the name (suggested by @Ruben Van de Velde in #12635). This should be quick to review.
Following the naming convention, this should be realExp, not rexp

But "rexp" is quite commonly used in this context. Also,

import Mathlib
open scoped Real
#check rexp

Or rather, the analogue for Complex.exp:
@loogle "_cexp"
:search: Set.Countable.preimage_cexp, iteratedDeriv_cexp_const_mul, and 25 more
:search: HasSum.rexp, Filter.Tendsto.rexp, and 4 more

Should lemmas about NormedSpace.exp then have normedSpaceExp in the name?

That question triggered the whole thing in #12635, because there were versions docs#Filter.Tendsto.cexp for the complex exponential and Filter.Tendsto.exp for the real one (then renamed to docs#Filter.Tendsto.rexp), so how to name a version for the normed space one? There was opposition to NormedSpace_exp or similar...

I don't think the naming convention is particularly clear regarding parts of names that come from namespaced things, BTW.
:search: Continuous.cexp, ContinuousAt.cexp, and 50 more
I guess all of these should then be renamed to mention "complexExp"...

Michael Stoll said:

I don't think the naming convention is particularly clear regarding parts of names that come from namespaced things,

I've clarified it recently:

#naming said:

When referring to a namespaced definition in a lemma name not in the same namespace, the definition should have its namespace removed. If the definition name is unambiguous without its namespace, it can be used as is. Else, the namespace is prepended back to it in lowerCamelCase. This is to ensure that _-separated strings in a lemma name correspond to a definition name or connective.

I think it is okay to create domain specific abbreviations for names like this, as long as we are consistent about it (i.e. using rexp everywhere, possibly including in theorems in the Real namespace)

I admit to not reading #naming every day...
I notice that this clarification comes very far down in the file (where I tend not to look when trying to figure some thing out). I would have expected that to be udner "General conventions".

Surely it should go under "Identifiers and theorem names"? Maybe it could be moved to just after

The hypotheses are listed in the order they appear, not reverse order. For example, the theorem A → B → C would be named C_of_A_of_B.

Would it make sense to have a table of contents near the top of the page? So that one sees that there is a section on "Identifiers and theorem names", for example (and can jump to it quickly; I guess this section is fairly important for Mathlib contributors).

Right now, when I open the page, I see "General conventions" and then "Examples", and it is not obvious that there is more to come after that.
